titleStmt.title: Transcription 2: 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' (BL, MS Egerton 2899)

availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects.

note.p: London, British Library, MS Egerton 2899, consists of a 14th-century psalter and a 15th-century (?) martyrology owned by the Campbells of Glenorchy through the 16th to the 18th century. In around 1500, 'Aingil Dé dom dhín', a Middle Gaelic verse lorica invoking the seven archangels and the twelve apostles, was inscribed on the flyleaf. On the whole, beyond names of angels and apostles, it consists of praise of their virtues and allusions to the dangers against which they protect the poet. In terms of language, there are some interesting early specimens and also some distinctive scribal traits that merit further investigation as possible examples of Scottish dialectal influence.

msContents.summary: 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' is the only Gaelic text in the manuscript; the martyrology shows a particular interest in Argyll saints (Flower 1926: 23) but it is entirely in Latin, as is the psalter.

note.p: The poem is a lorica-style litany, invoking the protection of the seven archangels (one for each day of the week) and the twelve apostles, praising their merits, and alluding to the dangers from which through them the dovotee is preserved. Some manuscripts attribute the poem to Colum Cille (Flower 1926: 24) but these are all late witnesses. Such an ascription is absent from earlier manuscripts, including Egerton 2899, and there is nothing in the text itself to particularly support it. It does, however, have a tendency to be selected by early scribes interested in Columban material (.i.e. the present scribe and the compilers of Laud Misc. 615)
The poem is bipartite. qq1–18 (in the Egerton 2899 text) invoke the protection of the seven archangels, while qq.19–30 invoke the proetection of the twelve apostles.

O'Nolan (1912: 253) suggests that these might have originally been two separate poems, as the section on the archangels closes with a dúnad. This seems plausible, as neither section depends on the other for sense, and the final quatrain, bearing a unifying dúnad, does not relate specifically to the second section. However, a dúnad need not always indicate the end of a poem but can indicate merely a shift in topic. Also, as shown below, all manuscript witnesses preserve at least some of both sections. Thus, if they were originally separate, their conjunction probably happened prior to the text's archetype and nothing can be known of their independent textual history. Nonetheless, the possibility of distinct origins should be borne in mind when assessing the language.

The metre is lethrannaigecht mór (51515151; abcb). The resulting short lines rarely come together within a quatrain to form a long developed sentence and more often contain a discrete prepositional phrase or short statement. The relentless interest throughout is the glorifying of God, the archangels, and the apostles, so the style remains distinctly panegyrical.

There is no glossing or annotation on 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' to indicate how readers interacted with the text. As it is placed on the flyleaf of a martyrology/psalter that was, or would shortly come to be, in the possession of an aristocratic family, one might speculate that the poem was used for devotional purposes. Just as the martyrology identifies feast days through the year and the psalter is drawn upon regularly in liturgical time, 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' identifies a heavenly protector for each day of each week. Whether the Campbells of Glenorchy and their associates would have struggled with the poem's occasional early forms should be considered, however: the poem could be more for ornamental value. On the other hand, the poem reseambles secular panegyric in terms of metre, imagery and tone. It has been pointed out (Flower 1926: 23) that Colin's father, Duncan, is attributed poetry in the Book of the Dean of Lismore (Edinburgh, NLS, Adv. MS 72.1.37), implying sustained interest in Gaelic literature on the part of this family.

The only edition of the text (which does not draw on Egerton 2899) is that of Thomas O'Nolan (1912). Flower (1926: 23–24) comments briefly upon it in his entry on Egerton 2899 in his Catalogue of Irish Manuscripts in the British Museum: Vol. 2. Ronald Black (2017: §128) repeats some of the essential details from O'Nolan and Flower and comments on the hand in the context of its contribution to Edinburgh, NLS, Adv. MS 72.1.31 (Black 2011: NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31). Any further extant work on the text is yet to be identified.

filiation.p:
When Thomas O'Nolan (1912) edited 'Aingil Dé dom dhín', he did not use Egerton 2899. Instead, he used eight Irish manuscripts:
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.P.16 (1230), 15th cent., An Leabhar Breac
Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Laud Misc. 615, 16th century
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.G.23 (256), 17th century
Dublin, Royal Irish Academy, MS 23.N.13 (???), date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, Murphy MS. 70, date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, Murphy MS. 39, date unknown
Maynooth, St Patrick’s College, O’Renehan MS. 96, date unknown
A copy in the O’Curry Mss. (unspecified), 19th century
The number and order of the quatrains in the different manuscript versions varies quite significantly. This can be used to show Egerton 2899’s affiliation within the tradition.

The Egerton 2899 text aligns structurally with the Leabhar Breac and Laud Misc. 615 texts. This is not particularly borne out by a comparison between the varia lectiones in O'Nolan's edition and the present witness, however. While the Egerton 2899 text does not consistently align with the others against the Leabhar Breac and Laud Misc. 615, it often presents its own distinctive readings against them.

It seems fairly likely that the omission of O'Nolan's q7 was a mistake at a certain point in the tradition. That is, it is not a later addition. O'Nolan's qq5–7 (represented by qq. 7 (= 5) and 8 (= 7) in Egerton 2899) list seven archangels, describing each of them as a “guarantor" (cuir). O'Nolan's q8 (= q7 in the Egerton 2899 text) then calls them “the seven guarantors on God's behalf" ('Seacht cuir dar cend De'). Given that three of these guarantors (Raphael, Painiel, and Gabriel) are enumerated in O'Nolan's q7, it was almost certainly in the original composition. The Leabhar Breac , Laud Misc. 615, and Egerton 2899 texts thus all have a common ancestor somewhere below the archetype where this omission occured. This archetype must have existed by the period 1408×1411, when the Leabhar Breac was produced.

As all other manuscripts of 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' are of Irish provenance, it seems reasonable to conclude in the absence of any other evidence that the poem was composed in Ireland. A relatively early stratum in the language suggests it was composed in the Middle Gaelic period.

note.p: The survey that follows draws solely on the Egerton 2899 text unless otherwise specified, as the present concern is with the language of this scribe and with this version of the poem as a Scottish literary artefact.

list.head: Vowels
list.item: A mixture of "ea" and "e" is used (e.g. "deamhan" (q29c), "spregadh" (q29d)), with "-ea-" predominating.
There are no instances of "io" for "i".

There is occasional heterodox treatment of dipthongs (e.g. "naeime" (q12d), acc. (or dat.) of noíbe). Sometimes, they are even simplified to a single vowel ("badal" (q15d), nom. sing. of báegul). Otherwise, the expected Middle Gaelic form of the dipthong is typically used (e.g. "naem" (q19c), nom. sing. of noíb; "taebh" (q28b), dat. sing. of taeb).

Unstressed final syllables occasionally show signs of the confusion and simplification of the vowel to /ə/ that characterised Middle Gaelic (e.g. "mo [sh]laintisi air" (q9c), nom. sing. of sláinte). However, they tend to remain appropriate to the grammatical case and number (e.g. "gom cridhe" (q28c), acc. sing. of críde.
A distinctive feature of this hand is the use of "y" for "i" (Black (2011: NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31), particularly in non-Gaelic names. This occurs in the present text: "symon" (q20d).
On two occasions, ríg is used for nominative (or possibly vocative) rí (q28d, q29a), anticipating Scottish Gaelic rìogh.

list.head: Accents
list.item: Accents are used, but erratically (e.g. "Da apstal dég de" (q19a, recte "Dá apstal dég dé").

There is a specific editorial problem with "i". The scribe routinely differentiates "i" from other minims (even when "i" is not in a minim cluster) through the use of an upward stroke that is inditinguishable from his accent. It is thus not possible to tell when, if ever, the scribe intended to mark a long "i" as í.
Accents are also quite erratically placed, sometimes even appearing over neighbouring consonants.

list.head: Consonants
list.item: Lenition of voiced and unvoiced dental stops in final position is usually shown (e.g. "gruadh" (q14a); "bith" (q15d)), but sometimes not (e.g. "urcanead" (q18a)).
Unaspirated voiceless velar stops in final position are typically not lenited (e.g. "sluag" (q1d)), with only one exception ("dluigh" (q4c)).

Aspirated voiceless velar stops (/k/) are frequently used in place of aspirated voiceless velar fricatives (/x/) at word end (e.g. "nac[h]" (q10d); "gac[h] domnaic[h]" (q14c); "toseac[h]" (q25b)). While not universal, this is occurs too regularly to be explicable by accidental omission of lenition marks.
Lenition of bilabial stop "b" in final position to a labio-dental fricative is typically shown (e.g. "cliabh" (q28c)).
Lenition of bilabial nasal "m" in final position to a labio-dental fricative is sometimes shown (e.g. "ad chiamh" (q18d)) but more often not (e.g. "niamh" (q6d)).

Final resonant "-nn" (/N/) is sometimes rendered as Middle Gaelic hypercorrection "-nd". For example, "ceand" is used throughout for cenn (e.g. "ceand" (q7a)); "-nd" is generally preferred in the text overall by 6:1.

A dot, or sometimes a very small tick, is occasionally placed over the "d" in final resonant "-nd", giving "-nḋ" (e.g. "sginḋ" (q30a)); this appears to be indicating that it is part of a consonant cluster and should not be taken as lenition, even though it resembles a lenition mark visually.

list.head: Initial Mutations
list.item: Lenition is marked (via a small tick) quite sproradically (e.g. "mo chul" (q22b), "dom dhin" (q29c), "a bharr" (q5d), "mo [sh]laintisi" (q9c); but "mo comla" (q25c), "os ma cind" (q25d)).

Eclipsis is marked by nasalising initial vowels (e.g. "Seacht nárćhaingil" (q2a)) and voiced stops (e.g. "ar urcanead ngur" (q18a)) and via voicing voiceless stops (e.g. "parrthalon na b[p]eann" (q20b)).

On two occasions, lenition is marked where eclipsis would be expected ("na cheall" (q2c), "of the churches"; "na fheart" (q10a), "of the virtues"). This may be intended as a catch-all marker of whatever the appropriate mutation might be.
Occasionally, eclipsis is not marked at all (e.g. "toseac[h] na fear find" (q25b)).

There are several examples of pronunciation spellings, in which the initial mutation is simplified or disappears entirely (e.g. "na b[p]eann" (q20b); "muire an [fh]irog fhind" (q20c); "ni gloir [fh]and" (q5b).

list.head: Letter Forms
list.item: Black (2011: NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31) has commented that this scribe employs a number of distinctive forms, compared to the norms of Gaelic scribal pratice at the time. Some of these are instanced in this text: for example, capital "T" consisting an upward stroke with a rightward half-stroke at top and bottom (resembling "[") (e.g. "T́igid" (q24a)) or "y" for "i" in names (e.g. "symon" (q20d)).
Double insular "s" is used to stand for "S" at the beginning of quatrains (e.g. "Seacht" (q2a)).
When "C" begins a new quatrain, it is slightly enlarged and a dot is placed inside the crescent (e.g. "Cor" (q5a)).
All other letters have their own capital form, used when the letter begins a quatrain.

The scribe regularly adds thin upward stroke above "i". This is very useful for distinguishing the letter in a minim cluster, but the stroke is indistinguishable from the length mark used elsewhere. It is thus not clear when, if ever, the scribe means to indicate a long "i".

list.head: Abbreviations
list.item: All abbreviations used in the text can be described as mainstream within Gaelic manuscript culture.
Most stand for just one or two characters (e.g. n-stroke, m-stroke).
Generic suspensions, standing for more lengthy strings of characters, are employed very rarely and only in the context of personal names.

list.head: Word Division
list.item: Spacing between words is in general quite irregular.

There is a tendency to use spacing to section off set prepositional phrases (e.g. "osmachind" (fol.iiir2)), noun phrases ("molaintisi" (i.e. "mo [sh]lainti-si") (fol.iiir9)), and verb complexes (e.g. "nacbi" (fol.iiir17)) and suchlike.
The scribe is also capable of rendering a sizeable portion of a quatrain with no notieable spacing between words, phrases, or even metrical lines (e.g. the rest of fol.iiir2; fol.iiir23).

list.head: Verse Layout
list.item: Each quatrain is set out in one continuous manuscript line, with only very occasional spillover (e.g. fol.iiir2).
A capital letter (indicated various ways) is used to introduce a new quatrain.
A punctus is used occasionally to separate metrical lines or quatrains, although it sometimes seems to be misplaced (e.g. q14a).

Dúinte are used to indicate the end of the poem (fol.iiir31) and the switchover from angels to apostles (fol.iiir18) (or the joining of two originally independant poems). They occur within the main text and are not sectioned off in any special way.

list.head: Corrections
list.item: There are no signs of any corrections having been made to the text by the original scribe or subsequently.

list.head: Other traits
list.item: As noted, the scribe not infrequently uses pronunciation spellings (e.g. "na b[p]eann" (q20b)). On other occasions, however, the forms that he renders imply a misunderstanding of the text's sense. For example, he appears to be referring to an eighth (otherwise unknown) archangel when he writes "scaphel blaith | a bharr" (fol.iiir5–6; "Scaphael, fine his helmet"); other manuscript witnesses have "scathfhial" ("sheltering veil") at this point. In another example, he suspiciously repeats "uriel" (fol.iiir10) in the verse on Archangel Uriel at a point where an adjective would be expected (= "ur[fh]iel", air- + fíal?), although there is confusion regarding this line throughout the manuscript witnesses (O'Nolan 1912: 255).

list.head: Nouns
list.item: There are several examples of preserved accusatives in the text ("ar urcanead ngur" (q18a); "re gach nimclog nar" (q24b)), although only following prepositions.

However, there are also possible examples of the accusative being replaced by the dative (e.g ."re báis ḃha[i]n" (q17d); "fam cliu" (q27a)), although the scribe elsewhere use a enition mark where eclipsis would be expected (see above)).)
There is also a potential example of hypercorrect eclipsis being used after the "subject" of a verbal noun as if it were the object of a verb.: "re dul an treas nuilc" (q21b)).

list.head: Adjectives
list.item: Adjectives mostly behave as expected. However, there are few examples of adjectives outside the nominative singular, or in the comparitive or superlative, so few diagnostic observations can be made.

There are a few examples of adjectives failing to be declined with the dative noun they describe; all concern clé (e.g. "fan chaingin chlé" (q1b); cf. q27a, where the dative form of the substantive (clíu) is used.).

list.head: Definite Article
list.item: All plural articles are monosyllabic (i.e. na).
There are no examples of articles with dative plural nouns (most happen to be genitive plural), so declension of the article cannot be tested.
In one case, a masculine article is used with an originally neuter noun: "an tolc" (q10d).

list.head: Personal Endings
list.item: There are no analytic verb forms in the text.
A relatively wide range of tenses, numbers, and moods are represented by synthetic forms.
Some Old Gaelic person endings are preserved and secured by rhyme (e.g. "at chiam" (:"biadh"; q1b)).
There are some examples of Middle Gaelic simple verbs formed from the prototonic form of compound verbs (e.g. "T́igid", from do-icc (q24a)).

On one occasion, the relative ending -as is used, although possibly in its original Old Gaelic usage as a relative future "dicras deamhan dim" (q30b; "[breastplate] ... that will drive back (?) a demon from me").
Another active relative form resists the Middle Gaelic generalisation of -as: "nac[h] blaisde" (q1d).

However, a relative passive plural ("nac[h] mhillter me tribh" (q3b; "so that they do not destroy me (?) through them")) undegoes initial lenition, perhaps showing the Middle Gaelic spread of the lenited relative clause (NB: the passive form with apparently active meaning is also problematic, given that millid is not deponent).
Occasionally, consonant confusion distorts the personal ending. For example, "mar tisat eac[h] } ur" (q24c, where the verb is almost certainly singular, despite the "-at" ending (leg. "-ad"(?).)

list.head: The Verbal Complex
list.item: There are relatively few preterites/perfects in this text; being oriented to devotion, its focus is on the present and the future.
The most common pre-verbal particle used is nach, with the conjunct form of the verb.
On its sole occurrence,ro is used perfectively: "re cech ngád (?) rom feith" (q6b; "against each danger he has protected me").
There are no occurences of do at all.

list.head: Infixed, Object, and Subject Pronouns
list.item: Infixed pronouns are used on several occasions (e.g. "nim ria a naine olc" (q12c)).

However, the independant object pronoun mé is also used on several occasions (e.g. "fetheat me ar rith uilc" (q26b)). All instances are found in metrically compliant lines and are also attested in other manuscript witnesses, so this is unlikely to be the product of late scribal slips. It could be a stylistic choice; in what is essentially a prayer, the poet is placing the emphasis on himself as a recipient of divine aid, hence only 1st-person object pronouns being used this way.
There are no subject pronouns used in the text.

list.head: Copula/Substantive
list.item: The use and forms of the verbs "to be", which do not appear frequently, seem largely standard for conservative Middle Gaelic.
There is one occurence of the copula's originally relative form as being used as a main verb ("as e an seachtmadh slan" (q14b)), evidencing Middle Gaelic vowel confusion.

The same example also shows another Middle Gaelic feature: a subject pronoun being used to support the copula. This is attested in other manuscript witnesses, although elision means that it cannot be said whether it is essential to the original text.

list.head: Personal
list.item: Very few independent personal pronouns are used in the text.
Emphatic pronominals and conjugated prepositions are more common.

list.head: Conjugated Prepositions
list.item: A prepositions conjugated with a possessive_pronoun and followed by a noun or verbal noun constitute a very common, quasi-verbal construction in the text (e.g. "Mata maith dom dhin" (q21a)).
There is one instance of preposition tre, which takes the accusative in Old Gaelic, being conjugated with a dative ("tribh" (q3b)).

list.head: Verb Phrases
list.item: A lot of verb phrases in the text are relative or subordinate. The quatrain as a whole usually has an angel or apostle or group thereof as its subject, with an implied optative or imperative verb "to be"; verb phases then occur within the structure relative to this subject.
There are no examples of preposition + verb relative construct.
With one aforementioned exception ("as e an seachtmadh slan" (q14b)), all instances of the copula and the substantive have a direct predicate.

list.head: Noun Phrases
list.item: As already noted, there are several examples of nouns in the accusative but only following appropriate prepositions. There are no clear examples of the accusative as the direct object.
There is also one potential hypercorrect use of the accusative to indicate the object of a verbal noun and several instances of the dative playing the role of the accusative.

Most lines in the poem consist of either a name and an epithet (e.g. "crist fein fear gan crith" (q15b)) or two noun phrases related to each other by a preposition, often conjugated with a possessive_pronoun (e.g. "dom saeradh go daith" (q15c)).

list.head: Adverbials
list.item: Adverbials are used sparingly in this text.
Adverbs are either free-standing words (e.g. "thuas" (q25a)) or formed out of co + adjective (e.g. "go daingin" (q11b)).

list.head: Specialised/Technical Vocabulary
list.item: Despite angels being a relatively esoteric subject, there are few terms in this text that could be described as specialised or technical.
The vocabulary, along with the imagery and sentiments, are reminiscent of secular panegyric. The language is thus far from plain but would be well-understood in mainstream literary terms.

list.head: Loanwords
list.item: There are naturally religious or ecclesiastical terms that were originally lonwords from Latin (or from Greek via Latin (e.g. "biaid" (q23b), from beati; "gloir" (q5b), from gloria; "apstal" (q19a), from apostola). However, most of these would have been well-established in Gaelic by the Middle Gaelic period, let alone by 1500.

note.p: 'Aingil De dom dhín' evidently has a significant early Middle Gaelic stratum and was probably composed in that era. The scribe renders most of the early features accurately. Most of the incongruities (e.g. pronunciation spellings, a curious approach to marking initial mutations) seem to be his own idiosyncracies. There are no widespread or wholesale modernisations that could be attributed to him or his late medieval scribal predcessors. It can therefore be concluded that this early text has been transmitted with reasonable accuracy, generally speaking.

The poem's presentation and context imply that it was meant to be presentable. Abbreviations are used sparingly, there are no glosses or corrections, and it fits most appositely into the manuscript in terms of content. It thus seems reasonable to assume that it was inscribed for devotional use, or at least inspiration, among the Campbells of Glenorchy alongside the martyrology and the psalter. To what extent a Middle Gaelic literary text would have posed comprehension problems in 16th-century Scotland outside of bardic circles is not clear. However, the formal bardic metre and general panegyric style would surely have offered ways into its appreciation for a reasonably cultured audience.

In terms of influence from Scottish Gaelic, this is certainly not widespread. "Ríg" is used for rí, the dative has expanded its role slightly at the expense of the accusative, and there is an instinct towards leniting relatives regardless of context, but these are isolated features and the examples of the latter two features are for the most part problematic. The scribe's consistent preference for "-c" over "-ch" and his erratic handling of initial mutations (sometimes using lenition marks where nasalisation is required, sometimes resorting to pronunciation spellings) perhaps merit further investigation, as they could turn out to represent points of tension between the language of the scribe and the literary Middle Gaelic of his text.

The poem is part devotional and part panegyric. It invokes the protection of the seven archangels and the twelve apostles, then finally Christ and the Holy Spirity, through expressing confidence in their holiness and efficacy. As such, it has much in common with secular praise poetry, with martial imagery regularly invoked to depict never-quite-specified spiritual dangers and their vanquishment by the entity being invoked. For example, Panael is said to act "fo rinḋ cathairm chuir[r]" (q14d: "against the point of a sharpened battle-weapon") and the two apostles called James are "sgiath fail ar mo sgath" (q22d; "a shield upon my back").

The structure is very straightforward. After a short preface praising the seven archangels (qq.1–7), one archangel is invoked for each day of the week (qq8–14). After a concluding set of stanzas on the archangels' collective efficacy (qq.15–18), the twelve apostles are introduced and invoked (qq.19–26. Many apostles share a stanza and Mary's protection is also briefly sought. The poem then ends with invocation of Christ and the Holy Spirit as the ultimate protection (qq.26–30). Despite this methodical structure, the poem is not particularly didactic. One would not learn very much from it about the angels, the apostles, or even about Christ, in terms of historical or theological information. The focus is instead on the needs and subjective faith of the poet/speaker.

Lethrannaigecht Mór, the metre, is not as strict as some in the bardic canon. It requires four lines of five syllables with a monosyllabic cadence, perfect end-rhyme between lines b and d, imperfect rhyme between a word in c and a word in d, and alliteration in each line (51515151, abcb). On the whole, this metre is adhered to throughout the poem in Egerton 2899. Alliteration is occasionally absent (e.g. q24a), there is one hypersyllabic line (q17a), and end-rhyme is imperfect on one occasion (q18b, c) without remedy via straightforward editorial emendation. It is questionable whether the scribe fully understood the demands of the metre, however, as some of his orthographic variants spoil the attendant rhymes. For example, an extra "r" has to be added to "chuir[r]" (q13d) to place it in the same class as "droing" (q13b).

physDesc.p: NB: The following description only covers the transcribed sections of the manuscript.

foliation.p: Modern; poem is inscribed on what was intended to be the flyleaf.

condition.p: The condition is very good; the entire text is perfectly legible.

layoutDesc.p: Single column; one quatrain per line.

note.p: A single hand (FnaG: Hand7) produces the entire text of 'Aingil De dom dhín'. This hand does not appear anywhere else in Egerton 2899 and the manuscript contains no explicit clues as to the scribe's identity. Its cataloguers (British Library 2016: sub num. Egerton MS 2899; Flower 1926: 23) dates the hand palaeographically to c.1500.

Black (2011: NLS Adv. MS 72.1.31) has speculated that he may have been a MacEwen, for two reasons:
The manuscript was in the possession of the Campbells of Glenorchy by 1523 at latest (see below); the MacEwens traditionally provided scholars to this family.
Certain unusual palaeographical features of this hand (see below) are shared with Neil MacEwen (fl. 1630).

The same scribe is also the sole hand in the first fragment (fols. 1–5) bound into the composite manuscript, Edinburgh, NLS Adv., MS 72.1.31. This fragment preserves at least 13 poems in his hand about or attributed to Colum Cille, although its poor condition frustrates close examination of many of them. The genre as whole has been examined in detail by Herbert (2005). Four of these poems, as well as a text of 'Aingil De dom dhín', appear in Oxford, Bodleiain Library, MS. Laud Misc 615, which Herbert and O'Sullivan (1973: 175) date to 1532×1545 and associate with the circle of scholars working on Columban material for the Ó Néills of Tyrone, NW Ireland. Furthermore, the page layout of the first fragment in NLS Adv. 72.1.31 — oblong pages with long lines, often one quatrain per line — resembles that of Laud Misc. 615. Indeed, the quatrains of 'Aingil De dom dhín' in Egerton 2899 are each also set out one to a line. This might suggest that the present scribe had intellectual contact with scholars in the north of Ireland and drew on similar literary resources.

summary.p: A 14th-century Latin Psalter, to which a Martyrology was later added in the late 15th- or early 16th-century. 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' was probably added around 1500. The manuscript seems to have been owned by the Campbells of Glenorchy during this period and remained in the possession of a branch of the family (the Earls of Breadalbane) in the 18th century.

origin.p: According to Flower (1926: 23), Egerton 2899 began life in the 14th century as a psalter.

provenance.p: About a century later, the psalter was joined by a tabulated martyrology. The latter’s emphasis is on Scottish saints, some very local to Argyll. This, combined with an inscription implying that the manuscript was the property of Colin Campbell, Laird of Glenorchy (d. 1523), and a 18th-century bookplate of his descendants, the Earls of Breadalbane suggests an Argyll provenance for the gathering containing the martyrology. 'Aingil Dé dom dhín' would have been added in this context (around 1500). Technically, the psalter could be from elsewhere.

acquisition.p: The manuscript was purchased for the British Museum's collections from Sotheby's in February 1912. How it came to be up for sale is unclear.

editorialDecl.p: This transcription raised few particular editorial issues that required deviation from standard encoding practice. On a few occasions, an editorial emendation of highly corrupt forms have been supplied from O'Nolan's edition (1912) using the <corr> element, which is usually used for editorial interventions by personnel on the FnaG project.

The scribe regularly identifies the letter "i" with an un upward stroke above the character resembling a length mark. Unfortunately, it is indistinguishable visually from the length marks he adds to other characters. It is thus not possible to tell when, if ever, he intended to add a length mark to an "i". For this reason, all length marks on "i" have been removed in the transcription.

metDecl.p: The poem's metre is lethrannaigecht mór (51, 51, 51, 51). The text is laid out with one quatrain per line in Egerton 2899.

refsDecl.p: References are to quatrain (qn; the <lg> element>) then to line (abcd; the <l> element) where the edited text would be the most appropriate to consult. When the diplomatic text or the manuscript would be the most appropriate, the reference is to the folio (the <pb> element), then the manuscript line number (the <lb> element).

revisionDesc.change: Revised text in response to feedback
